div.l: To pleyn at þe dys in suche a strete
For in the toun nas þer no prentys
That fairer couthe cast a peire of dys
Then ꝐPerkyn couthe ⁊and þerto he was free
Of his dispence in place of pryuyte
That fonde his maister wel in his chaffare
For oft tyme he fond his box ful bare
For sikerly a p̉rentys reuelour
That haunteth dys riot or ꝑparamour
His maister shuld it in his shop a bie
Al haue he not part of þe mynstralcie
For theft and riot thei ben conuertible
Al con he pleie on giterne or rubible
Reuel and trouth as in a lowh degree
Thei ben ful wroth al day as men may see
This Iolye prentis with his maister boode
Til he were nyghe oute of his prentys hoode
Al were he snybbit erly and late
And somtyme lad with Reuel to Newgate
But at last his maister him by þoghte
Vppon a day whan he his paper sought
Of a ꝓproủerbe þat saith þis same word
Wel bet is roten appil out of hoord
Than þat it rotet al þe remenant
So farith it by a riotous seruant
It is ful lasse harme to late him passe
Than he shend alle the seruauntz in þe place
Therfore his maister ȝaf him a quytance
And bad him goo with soroo and myschance
And thus this Ioly prentys had his leue
Now let him riot al the nyght or leue
And for ther is no theof wit oute a look
That helpith him to wasten and to sowke
Of that he brybe can or borow may
Anoon he sent his bedde and his array
Vnto a conꝑper of his owne sort
That loued dys Reuel and disport
And had a wif þat held for cōntynance
A shope and swyfed for hire sustynance
But here of I wil passe as now
And of ȝong Gamalyne I will telle ȝow
